questions: When will my root canal claim of Rs 25,000 be settled?
I have done an IVF for Rs 56,000. Is it covered?
I did a cataract treatment of Rs 100,000. Will you settle the full Rs 100,000?
Give me a list of documents to be uploaded for hospitalization for heart surgery.
answers: The company will settle or reject your root canal claim within 15 days from the date the last necessary document is received. If an investigation is required, this timeline extends to 45 days from the receipt of the last document.

Based on the provided text, expenses related to assisted reproduction services, including advanced reproductive technologies such as IVF, are not covered under this policy. Therefore, your IVF procedure for Rs 56,000 is not covered.

For cataract treatment, the company will indemnify medical expenses up to 25% of your Sum Insured or INR 40,000 per eye, whichever is lower, per policy period. This means the full Rs 100,000 might not be settled depending on your policy's Sum Insured and the specific limit per eye.

For hospitalization for heart surgery, you'll need a duly completed claim form, photo identity proof, the medical practitioner's prescription for admission, original itemized bills, payment receipts, and the discharge summary. Additionally, submit investigation/diagnostic test reports, OT notes or a surgeon's certificate detailing the operation, and implant stickers/invoices if applicable.

questions: Is Non-infective Arthritis covered?
I renewed my policy yesterday, and I have been a customer for the last 6 years. Can I raise a claim for Hydrocele?
Is abortion covered?
answers: Yes, Non-infective Arthritis is listed as a condition with a four-year waiting period, as indicated in Table B.

Yes, you can raise a claim for Hydrocele. The policy can be renewed even if you have made claims in preceding policy years, and renewal is generally not denied except on grounds of fraud or misrepresentation.

The policy covers expenses for lawful medical termination of pregnancy during the policy period, unless it's due to an accident. However, expenses incurred for voluntary medical termination of pregnancy within the first twelve weeks from the date of conception are not covered.

questions: What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
answers: According to Article 1 of the Constitution, the official name of India is "India, that is Bharat." This article also states that India shall be a Union of States.
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of the laws to all persons within the territory of India. The State shall not deny any person these rights.
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes untouchability and forbids its practice in any form. Any disability arising from untouchability is an offense punishable by law.

The Preamble to the Constitution of India declares the ideals of establishing India as a Sovereign Socialist Secular Democratic Republic and securing Justice (social, economic, and political), Liberty (of thought, expression, belief, faith, and worship), Equality (of status and opportunity), and Fraternity assuring the dignity of the individual and the unity and integrity of the Nation for all its citizens.

Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution of India. This process requires a bill to be introduced with the President's recommendation, and if the proposal affects a State's area, boundaries, or name, the bill must be referred to that State's Legislature for its views.
According to Article 24 of the Constitution of India, children below the age of fourteen years are prohibited from working in any factory or mine or engaging in any other hazardous employment.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the protection of life and personal liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of their life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law. This fundamental right is a cornerstone of individual freedom within the Indian legal framework.

Under Article 15, the State can make special provisions for women and children, as well as for the advancement of any socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens, particularly concerning admission to educational institutions.
Article 11 grants Parliament the authority to regulate the acquisition and termination of citizenship and all other related matters, thereby allowing it to override previous articles on citizenship.

Under Article 19(2), the State can impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech and expression in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, public order, morality, friendly relations with foreign States, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. These restrictions can also be imposed for the security of the State, public safety, or maintaining public order.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: The provided text does not specify the legal case category for a stolen car. However, it does mention that no person shall be deprived of their property except by the authority of law.

The provided text does not directly address whether an arrest without a warrant is legal. However, it does state that any person arrested must be produced before a magistrate within twenty-four hours, excluding travel time, and cannot be detained beyond that period without a magistrate's authority, unless the person is an enemy alien or arrested under a preventive detention law.

No, it is not allowed. The Constitution of India states that no citizen shall be ineligible for or discriminated against in any employment or office under the State solely on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, or residence.

The Constitution of India states that no law providing for the acquisition by the State of any estate or rights therein can be deemed void on grounds of inconsistency with fundamental rights. However, if the land acquired is under personal cultivation and within the applicable ceiling limit, the law must provide compensation at a rate not less than the market value.
No, it is not legal to employ a child under the age of fourteen in any factory. Furthermore, traffic in human beings and forced labor are prohibited and considered offenses punishable by law.
All citizens have the right to freedom of speech and expression, and to assemble peaceably and without arms. Therefore, if you are stopped from speaking at a protest, it would be against your rights.

No citizen can be subjected to any disability or restriction solely based on sex, as the State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth, or any of them. However, nothing in this article prevents the State from making any special provision for women and children.

Yes, you are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health. However, the state can regulate or restrict economic, financial, political, or other secular activities associated with religious practice.

The provided text chunks do not directly specify which right is violated if the police torture someone in custody. However, Article 32 guarantees the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

No citizen can be denied admission to an educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid from the State solely on the grounds of religion, race, caste, or language. The Constitution also allows for the President to specify socially and educationally backward classes through public notification, and for Parliament to include or exclude classes from this list by law.

questions: How does Newton define 'quantity of motion' and how is it distinct from 'force'?
According to Newton, what are the three laws of motion and how do they apply in celestial mechanics?
How does Newton derive Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) from his laws of motion and gravitation?
How does Newton demonstrate that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses?
What is Newton's argument for why gravitational force must act on all masses universally?
How does Newton explain the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets?
What mathematical tools did Newton use in Principia that were precursors to calculus, and why didn't he use standard calculus notation?
How does Newton use the concept of centripetal force to explain orbital motion?
How does Newton handle motion in resisting media, such as air or fluids?
In what way does Newton's notion of absolute space and time differ from relative motion, and how does it support his laws?
Who was the grandfather of Isaac Newton?
Do we know any other descent of Isaac Newton apart from his grandfather?
answers: Newton defines the "quantity of motion" as the measure derived from the velocity and quantity of matter combined. This is distinct from "force," which he describes as an action that causes a change in a body's state of motion or rest, and which ceases to exist once the action is over.

According to Newton, the three laws of motion are: Law I, stating that every body perseveres in its state of rest or of uniform motion in a right line unless compelled to change that state by impressed forces; Law II, asserting that the alteration of motion is proportional to the motive force impressed and made in the direction of that force; and Law III, which posits that to every action there is always an equal and opposite reaction. Newton's laws are fundamental to celestial mechanics, explaining the motions of planets, satellites, and comets by demonstrating how bodies, such as planets and comets in free space, preserve their progressive and circular motions for extended periods due to minimal resistance.

Newton derives Kepler's Second Law by considering a body acted upon by a centripetal force. He demonstrates that if this force acts in successive impulses, causing the body to move in straight lines within infinitesimal time intervals, the triangles formed by the center of force and consecutive positions of the body are equal in equal times. By composition, this means that equal areas are described in equal times, all lying within the same plane.

Newton demonstrates that the force of gravity towards any particle of a body is reciprocally proportional to the square of the distance from that particle. He further establishes that when two spheres mutually gravitate, their weight towards each other is reciprocally as the square of the distance between their centers, provided the matter around their centers is similar and equidistant.

Newton's argument for the universality of gravitational force stems from his observation that attractive forces are compounded from the forces of component parts, as seen in magnetic and electric attractions. He reasoned that since all terrestrial bodies, regardless of form, possess attractive forces proportional to their matter, these forces must also be present in celestial bodies, acting in proportion to their mass.

Newton explains that the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets arises from their mutual gravitational actions. These perturbations are generally small, though some, like the disturbance of Earth's orbit by the Moon, are noticeable, and significant ones occur, such as Jupiter's action on Saturn.
In *Principia*, Newton utilized his "Method of first and last ratios," which was a precursor to calculus. The provided text does not specify why he didn't use standard calculus notation.

Newton explains orbital motion by defining centripetal force as that which draws bodies towards a center, like gravity drawing objects to Earth or the force keeping planets in orbit. Without this force, which opposes the natural tendency of bodies to move in straight lines, they would fly off into space.

Newton suggests that a projectile moving swiftly in a fluid encounters resistance that is nearly in the duplicate ratio of its velocity. This resistance arises from the excess of fluid pressure at the front of the projectile compared to its rear, and it acts to retard the projectile's motion.

Newton's concept of absolute space and time posits that space remains unchanging and immovable, and time flows equably regardless of external factors, forming the basis for true motion. This contrasts with relative motion, where an object's place and motion are defined by its relation to other moving objects, like a ship or the Earth. Absolute space and time provide an immovable reference frame against which all motions can be accurately measured and distinguished from apparent or relative motions, thereby supporting the understanding of forces that generate motion.
Sir Isaac Newton's grandfather was Robert Newton. Beyond him, the text does not definitively trace his lineage.

Beyond his grandfather, Robert Newton, the descent of Sir Isaac Newton cannot be traced with certainty. However, there are traditions suggesting their family was either of Scotch extraction or originated from Newton in Lancashire.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: If your car is stolen, it would be considered a criminal case under the category of theft, which is addressed by criminal law as included in the Indian Penal Code. The specific legal procedures and implications would depend on the laws in force at the time of the theft.

If you are arrested without a warrant, it can be legal under certain conditions. The Constitution of India allows for preventive detention under laws made by Parliament for reasons such as the security of the state or public order. Additionally, any person arrested must be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours, excluding travel time, unless detained under preventive detention laws.

No, it is not allowed to deny someone a job because of their caste. According to Article 16 of the Constitution of India, there shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State, and no citizen shall be discriminated against on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence, or any of them.

If the government takes your land for a project, you cannot stop it if the acquisition is done by the authority of law. According to Article 300A, no person shall be deprived of their property except by authority of law, and laws providing for the acquisition of estates or rights therein are not deemed void even if they modify or extinguish such rights, provided they comply with legal requirements, including compensation at market value for certain types of land.

No, it is not legal for your child to be forced to work in a factory. According to the Constitution of India, Article 24 prohibits the employment of children below the age of fourteen years in any factory, mine, or other hazardous employment.

Under the Constitution of India, all citizens have the right to freedom of speech and expression and the right to assemble peaceably and without arms, as stated in Article 19(1)(a) and (b). If you are stopped from speaking at a protest, it may infringe upon these rights, unless specific legal restrictions apply, such as those related to public order, morality, or health, which are not detailed in the provided text.

Under Article 25 of the Constitution of India, all persons are entitled to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health. However, Article 26 allows religious denominations to manage their own affairs in matters of religion, which may include restrictions on entry based on gender. Therefore, while there is a general right to access religious places, specific restrictions imposed by religious denominations may be constitutionally permissible.

Under **Article 25** of the Constitution of India, every person is entitled to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health. Therefore, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion, although it may regulate associated secular activities.

If the police torture someone in custody, it violates the **Right against Exploitation** as outlined in Article 23 of the Constitution of India, which prohibits "traffic in human beings and forced labour" and considers any contravention of this provision an offence punishable by law.

If you are denied admission to a public university because you belong to a backward community, you have legal recourse under the Constitution of India. Article 29(2) states that no citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language, or any of them. Additionally, Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of these rights.

If the police torture someone in custody, it violates the individual's **Fundamental Rights** as outlined in the Constitution of India, specifically under the provisions related to the right against exploitation and the prohibition of inhumane treatment.

If you are denied admission to a public university because you belong to a backward community, this would be a violation of your rights. According to Article 29(2) of the Constitution of India, no citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language, or any of them.

If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?

If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: The provided text does not contain specific information about the legal classification or case type for car theft. Therefore, the information regarding what case car theft would be classified under in law is not available in the text.

If you are arrested without a warrant, it can be legal under certain conditions. According to the Constitution of India, any person who is arrested must be produced before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours, excluding travel time, unless they are an enemy alien or detained under a law providing for preventive detention.

No, it is not allowed for someone to deny you a job because of your caste. According to Article 16 of the Constitution of India, there shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State, and no citizen shall be discriminated against on grounds of caste, among other factors.

If the government takes your land for a project, you cannot stop it if the acquisition is done under a law that provides for such acquisition. However, the law must ensure compensation at a rate not less than the market value of the land, especially if it is under personal cultivation and within the ceiling limit applicable to you.

No, it is not legal for your child to be forced to work in a factory. According to the Constitution of India, Article 24 prohibits the employment of children below the age of fourteen years in any factory, mine, or other hazardous employment.

Under the Constitution of India, all citizens have the right to freedom of speech and expression, as well as the right to assemble peaceably and without arms, as stated in Article 19(1). If you are stopped from speaking at a protest, it may infringe upon these rights, unless the restriction is justified under reasonable grounds such as public order, morality, or health.

The Constitution of India, under **Article 25**, grants all persons the freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health. However, **Article 26** allows every religious denomination or any section thereof the right to manage its own affairs in matters of religion, which could include the right to restrict entry based on gender. Therefore, while individuals have the right to religious freedom, religious institutions also have certain rights to manage their internal affairs, which may include gender-based entry restrictions.

Under **Article 25** of the Constitution of India, every person is entitled to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health. Therefore, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion, as this right is protected, although it is subject to certain conditions.

If the police torture someone in custody, it violates the **Right against Exploitation** as outlined in Article 23 of the Constitution of India, which prohibits "traffic in human beings and forced labour" and any similar forms of exploitation.

If you are denied admission to a public university because you are from a backward community, you have legal grounds to challenge this decision. According to the Constitution of India, no citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language, or any of them. Additionally, Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of these rights.
